People who have been o=
n the list a while have seen some good answers to that
question, but I'm ha=
ppy to take another swipe at it.  JUnit is built on the
assumption that you=
r tests are cheap to initialize and run.

1) If your tests are cheap to ini=
tialize and run, then running each test
method on a distinct instance of a =
class gives the added benefit of ensuring
that tests are independent.  I ha=
ve several times had functional tests pass
when they should have failed, be=
cause I've forgotten to delete a file
created in one test before another te=
st runs.  I'm glad that JUnit doesn't
add in the potential confusion of sta=
te changed in one test affecting the
next test.

2a) If your tests are not =
cheap to initialize and run and you're calling
them unit tests, it's worth =
taking a look at whether there's a way to test
what the unit under test doe=
s without expensive persistent state.  Often,
this thinking results in valu=
able design insights.

2b) If your tests are not cheap to initialize and ru=
n because they're
actually integration tests, acceptance tests, or end-to-e=
nd system tests,
then you might want state to persist, trading off safety f=
or performance.
In JUnit 3.8, you can use TestSetup for this state, and in =
JUnit 4, you can
use @BeforeClass with statics, or you can search Google fo=
r "JUnit
OneInstance.class", which will give you a solution allowing you to=
 only
instantiate your test class once.

Then again, I am in the camp of pe=
ople who think that maintaining
> immutable state in tests is not only harm=
less, it's actually very
> useful.  Which is why TestNG will not reinstanti=
ate your test classes
> like JUnit does.


If I couldn't get my design deco=
upled enough to run my unit tests without
expensive state, I might also tra=
de off safety for performance the way
TestNG does.  With a reasonable objec=
t-oriented language, it seems that
never happens for me.
